toc_entry.title: The Legacy Of Lee Harvey Oswald
toc_entry.description: Twenty years ago he thrust himself into our lives; he is there yet.

toc_entry.title: Why Do They Hate Us So Much?
toc_entry.description: A great man was dead and an outraged world desperately wanted someplace to lay the blame. It chose Dallas and changed the city forever.

toc_entry.title: Still On the Case
toc_entry.description: Assassination buffs come in all shapes and convictions—archivists, technologists, mob-hit theorists, and more—but they are all obsessed with Lee Harvey Oswald, and his crime is the focus of their lives.

toc_entry.title: The Wild Ones
toc_entry.description: Quick! Get out your furs before it gets hot again.

toc_entry.title: Fantasy Island
toc_entry.description: It’s a high-rise developer’s dream. Houston’s old guard wants to turn 34 acres of downtown warehouses into an island of classy shops and pricey condos. They thought they had it wired, until Kathy Whitmire was elected mayor.

toc_entry.title: Twofers
toc_entry.description: Texas: land of contrast. That’s why we have double-barreled businesses like a feedstore cum twirling school or a combo junkyard-wildlife preserve.

toc_entry.title: The Drill Team
toc_entry.subtitle: Texas Primer
toc_entry.description: Good, clean sex, brought to you by high-kicking, rosy-cheeked Texas gals.

toc_entry.title: The Roadside Eye
toc_entry.subtitle: Art
toc_entry.description: Robert Frank took casual but expressive snapshots that captured dramas of american life and altered the course of modern photography.

toc_entry.title: Cool Minds In a Hot War
toc_entry.subtitle: Movies
toc_entry.description: Nick Nolte is a journalist dodging bullets and political involvement in Under Fire. The Right Stuff is about americans, space, and manifest destiny. The Big Chill is a warm look at the cooling of sixties idealism.

toc_entry.title: A Surfeit Of Bimbos
toc_entry.subtitle: Books
toc_entry.description: In The Desert Rose Larry McMurtry’s heroines never blossom into believable women. The Franchise is a tough tale about graft and the gridiron.

toc_entry.title: Duel For the Sun
toc_entry.subtitle: Politics
toc_entry.description: Crosbyton and Texas Tech wanted to harvest a major local resource: the sun. But then the feds stepped in, and the issue switched from energy to power.

toc_entry.title: A Soprano Is Born
toc_entry.subtitle: Classical Music
toc_entry.description: Houston likes to think it discovered Erie Mills, but it’s willing to share the winning young star with the rest of the opera world.

toc_entry.title: Local Menu Makes Good
toc_entry.subtitle: Texana
toc_entry.description: Here’s to the unsung heroes of Eastland: my grandfather and his V. C. menu.

toc_entry.title: The Palace Of Pros
toc_entry.subtitle: Theater
toc_entry.description: With The Palace of amateurs, the Plaza Theatre brought a sparkling Mariel Hemingway to Dallas and a lofty new theatrical standard to Texas.

toc_entry.title: Around the State
toc_entry.description: A selective statewide guide to amusements and events.

toc_entry.title: Reporter
toc_entry.description: A new era for Texas prisons; a new view of Wichita Falls; a new look, alas, for a Dallas street; a new metropolis in East Texas; a new generation of frat rats.

toc_entry.title: State Secrets
toc_entry.description: The Supreme Court scores one for Texas against the Yankees; blame the recession on InterFirst; why Phil Gramm makes a great Republican; an oil squabble matches the greedy little independents against poor, starving Big Oil.
